access.description: The registered URL returns HTTP 200 directly with no redirects. The page is a HubSpot-hosted compliance hub with multiple FAQ accordion sections. The EHI export documentation is inside an accordion labeled 'B10 Documentation' which must be clicked to expand. However, the HTML content is present in the DOM source and accessible via curl without JavaScript. No anti-bot protection or special headers needed. Cloudflare CDN served the page without issues.

products.name: InteliChart Patient Portal

product_context.description: InteliChart Patient Portal is not an EHR — it is an EHR-agnostic patient engagement platform that integrates with 40+ EHR systems (athenahealth, Cerner/Oracle, Allscripts, Meditech, NextGen, Nextech, Netsmart, Greenway, PointClickCare, etc.) via API. The certified module is part of the broader 'Healthy Outcomes' suite which includes eight modules: Patient Portal (record access hub), Patient Schedule (online self-scheduling), Patient Intake (digital registration, consent forms, insurance OCR capture), Patient Notify (appointment reminders), Family Portal (LTC/SNF family communication), Patient Survey (PHQ-9, satisfaction surveys, PROMs), Patient Activate (population health campaigns), and Patient eHealth (telehealth). While InteliChart receives clinical data from connected EHRs, it also generates and stores substantial portal-native data: secure messages, intake forms, survey responses, scheduling data, insurance card images, bill payments, campaign records, telehealth sessions, and family communications. This portal-native data is arguably the most important data InteliChart uniquely stores, yet the export appears focused on clinical data passthrough from the EHR.

export_approach.description: The EHI export is primarily C-CDA/document-based. For single patients, the export produces a ZIP containing a C-CDA XML file (conformant to USCDI v1), encounter notes as PDF/HTML files, and patient documents as PDF/ZIP files. For patient population exports, the same per-patient structure applies with the addition of CSV data files. The overview PDF mentions FHIR Bulk Data Access (HL7 R4.0.1) and 'Clinical, Administrative and Financial reports,' but the detailed export structure described in the instructions is centered on C-CDA documents and PDF/HTML attachments. The method of export is described as 'CCDs through the Practice Portal' — essentially a clinical document export, not a database dump. The overview PDF references 'Data Format Specifications (ZIP)' files that are not publicly linked on the compliance page, so the detailed schema specifications are unavailable. This is a C-CDA-first approach that inherently limits what can be exported to what C-CDA supports, which excludes most portal-native data.

documentation_quality.description: The documentation is extremely thin — three PDFs totaling 5 pages (1+2+2) providing only high-level overviews. There is no data dictionary, no field-level documentation, no schema definitions, no table or resource enumeration. The single patient and population export PDFs are nearly identical, differing only in the addition of CSV files for population exports. The overview PDF references 'Data Format Specifications (ZIP)' files that are not publicly available on the compliance page, suggesting the most detailed technical documentation is missing. The only specific format detail is the file naming convention and directory structure (C-CDA XML, encounter PDFs, patient document PDFs). Data elements are listed only as five high-level categories (Demographics, Clinical Notes, Vital Signs, Laboratory, Procedures) with no field-level breakdown. References USCDI v1 (July 2020), which is significantly outdated.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The EHI export covers basic clinical data via C-CDA (demographics, notes, vitals, labs, procedures) and includes document attachments as PDFs. However, as a patient engagement platform that generates and stores substantial portal-native data — secure messages, intake forms, survey responses, scheduling history, insurance card captures, bill payments, campaign records, telehealth sessions, and family communications — the export appears to cover only the clinical data passthrough from connected EHRs while omitting the data InteliChart uniquely generates. The C-CDA format fundamentally cannot represent most of this portal-native data. The 'may include where applicable' qualifier on all content categories, the extremely thin documentation, and the missing specification ZIP files make it impossible to confirm exactly what is included. The mention of 'Clinical, Administrative and Financial reports' for population exports suggests some non-clinical data may be included as report documents, but no details are provided. Overall, this appears to be a minimal-effort compliance approach rather than a comprehensive EHI export.

clinical.evidence: C-CDA XML file conformant to USCDI v1 includes demographics, clinical notes, vital signs, laboratory results, and procedures. Encounter notes exported as separate PDF/HTML files in Encounters subfolder. Patient documents exported as PDF/ZIP in Patient Documents subfolder. Medications, allergies, and problem lists are implicitly included via USCDI v1 C-CDA but not explicitly listed in the documentation.

secure_messages.evidence: No mention of messages, inbox, communication, secure messaging, or portal correspondence in any of the three documentation PDFs. InteliChart's Patient Portal supports bidirectional secure messaging between patients and providers, and the Family Portal has threaded family-staff communications — both generating portal-native data that the platform stores. C-CDA has no standard mechanism for portal messaging threads. This is a significant gap: the data InteliChart uniquely generates (as opposed to clinical data passed through from the EHR) is not represented in the export.

billing_financial.evidence: The overview PDF mentions 'Clinical, Administrative and Financial reports' as part of the population export data, but provides no specifics about what financial data is included. No billing tables, charge records, payment details, or financial data structures are documented. The product has bill payment capabilities with flexible payment plans and copay collection through Patient Intake. The vague mention of 'financial reports' may refer to summary PDF reports rather than transactional billing data. Without the missing specification ZIP files, it is impossible to confirm what financial data, if any, is actually exported.

insurance_coverage.evidence: No mention of insurance, coverage, eligibility, payer, or benefits data in any of the three documentation PDFs. The Patient Intake module captures insurance card images via OCR and collects insurance information during registration. This data is generated and stored by InteliChart but does not appear in the export documentation. OCR-captured insurance card images are almost certainly not included in the C-CDA export.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No mention of appointments, scheduling, booking, or visit history data in the export documentation. The Patient Schedule module provides full 24/7 online self-scheduling with two-way EHR integration, generating scheduling data that InteliChart stores. Standard C-CDA does not include scheduling records. The 'Administrative' component mentioned in the population export overview may or may not include appointment data — no details are provided.

documents_images.evidence: The export structure includes an 'Encounters' subfolder with all visit notes as PDF/HTML files ({encounterId}_{date}.pdf or .html) and a 'Patient Documents' subfolder with other documents as PDF or ZIP files ({documentId}_{date}.pdf or .zip). This covers documents stored in the portal, though it's unclear whether all document types are included (e.g., OCR-captured insurance cards, uploaded images, faxes).

issues: C-CDA as primary export format severely limits coverage — cannot represent portal-native data like secure messages, intake forms, surveys, scheduling, campaigns, or telehealth sessions.
Missing 'Data Format Specifications (ZIP)' files — the overview PDF references these but they are not linked on the compliance page, so detailed schema documentation is unavailable.
Extremely thin documentation: 5 total pages across 3 PDFs with no data dictionary, no field-level detail, no schema definitions.

Portal-native data likely excluded from export — as a patient engagement platform, InteliChart uniquely generates and stores messages, forms, surveys, scheduling, campaigns, and telehealth data that the C-CDA export cannot represent.
'May include where applicable' qualifier on all content descriptions creates ambiguity about what patients actually receive.
USCDI v1 (July 2020) reference is significantly outdated — USCDI v4 was current as of late 2024.
Single patient and population export documentation is nearly identical — appears to be copied with minimal differentiation.
Five explicitly listed data elements (Demographics, Clinical Notes, Vital Signs, Laboratory, Procedures) is a narrow subset even of what C-CDA supports.
Encounter notes exported as PDF/HTML rather than structured data — not machine-readable for clinical content within the notes.
products.summary: InteliChart Patient Portal is an EHR-agnostic patient engagement platform with messaging, scheduling, intake forms, surveys, bill payment, and telehealth capabilities. Its EHI export is a C-CDA-based document export that covers basic clinical data passthrough from connected EHRs but appears to exclude the substantial portal-native data that InteliChart uniquely generates and stores. The documentation is minimal (5 pages total), references specification ZIP files that are not publicly available, and uses outdated USCDI v1. This represents a significant compliance concern given the breadth of data the platform stores.

downloaded_files.description: EHI Export Overview — 1-page PDF with high-level description of export capability, table listing export types (single patient and population), data contents, and reference to FHIR Bulk Data Access. Last updated 4/30/2024.

Single Patient EHI Export Data Overview and User Instructions — 2-page PDF describing export process, data elements (Demographics, Clinical Notes, Vital Signs, Laboratory, Procedures), export format (C-CDA XML + encounter PDFs + patient document PDFs), and file naming conventions. Last updated 4/30/2024.

Patient Population EHI Export Data Overview and User Instructions — 2-page PDF, nearly identical to single patient version. Same export structure with addition of CSV data files for population export. Last updated 4/30/2024.

summary: InteliChart LLC publishes minimal EHI export documentation (3 PDFs, 5 pages total) on a HubSpot-hosted compliance page behind an FAQ accordion. The export is C-CDA-based, covering basic clinical data from connected EHRs, but the InteliChart Patient Portal is a broad patient engagement platform with secure messaging, scheduling, intake forms, surveys, bill payment, and telehealth — most of which generates portal-native data that cannot be represented in C-CDA and appears absent from the export. Referenced specification ZIP files are not publicly linked. This is among the thinnest EHI export documentation we've encountered, raising significant questions about whether the export covers all EHI the product stores.
notes: The overview PDF references 'FHIR Bulk Data Access backed on HL7 Standard Release 4.0.1' and states it 'contains all available FHIR resources for the exported patient CCD/C-CDA Documents.' This phrasing is confusing — it seems to describe FHIR resources derived from C-CDA documents rather than a native FHIR export. The population export additionally mentions CSV files and 'Clinical, Administrative and Financial reports/images,' but no details are provided about what these contain. The certification criteria include (e)(1) for patient portal view/download/transmit and (e)(3) for patient health information capture, acknowledging that InteliChart captures patient-generated data, yet the export mechanism appears to exclude this data. Contact information for compliance inquiries: compliance@intelichart.com, 866.957.8890.
